tn.text: "It happened after this." This phrase is used to introduce a new event to the storyline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
sister** - Amnon and Tamar shared the same father but not the same mother.
Absalom and Tamar shared the same father and mother.

tn.ref: Amnon was so frustrated that he became sick because of his sister Tamar
tn.text: Amnon was frustrated because he desired to sleep with his sister Tamar. AT:  "Amnon was so frustrated with desire for his sister Tamar that he felt sick" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Jehonadab son of Shammah, David's brother
tn.text: These are the names of men. Shammah was David's brother. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
crafty or deceptive
in an emotional state of extreme unhappiness

The missing words may be added to this question. Also, this rhetorical question is a request for Jehonadab to tell him why he is depressed. It may be written as a statement. AT: "Will you not tell me why you are depressed?" or "Please, tell me why you are depressed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:13:03|13:03]].

tn.ref: and eat it from her hand ... I may eat from her hand
tn.text: This is a request for her to serve food to him personally. AT: "and have her serve it to me herself ... she may serve it to me to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means he gave a false appearance of being ill.

tn.ref: for my sickness in front of me
tn.text: The food is not for his sickness, but rather it is for him, because he is sick. The phrase "in front of me" is a request for Tamar to prepare the food in his presence. AT: "in front of me because I am sick" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means that he sent a messenger to speak to Tamar. AT: "David sent a messenger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
a thick mixture of flour and liquid used for baking
used her hands to mix the dough
This means that Tamar made the bread in front of him. AT: "in front of him" or "in his presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: So everyone went out from him
tn.text: To "go out from someone" means to leave them. AT: "So everyone left him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: that I may eat from your hand
tn.text: This is a request for Tamar to serve the food to him personally. AT: "and serve it to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The missing words may be added. AT: "do not force me to sleep with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
very shameful
Tamar continues to talk to Amnon.

tn.ref: How could I be rid of my shame?
tn.text: Tamar asks this rhetorical question to emphasize how much shame she would have if she slept with him. Tamar speaks of getting rid of her shame as if it were an enemy or a tormentor that she needed to escape from. AT: "If you do this, I would have to endure shame everywhere I go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Because this great evil of making me leave is even worse
tn.text: The abstract noun "this great evil" can be expressed as a verb. AT: "It would be very evil to make me leave! It would be even worse" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This means to lock the door so that she will not be able to come back in again. AT: "lock the door so that she cannot come back in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This means to lock the door so that she will not be able to come back in again. AT: "locked the door so that she could not go back in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit|Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])

tn.ref: put ashes on her head and tore her robe. She put her hands on her head
tn.text: These are acts of mourning and grief in the Israelite culture. AT: " put ashes on her head and tore her robe to show that she was very sad. Then to show her grief, she put her hands on her head" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction|Symbolic Action]])

tn.ref: Has Amnon your brother been with you?
tn.text: This is a polite way to ask is Amnon has had sexual relations with her. AT: "Has Amnon your brother slept with you?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This means to not tell anyone about something. AT: "do not tell anyone about this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Do not take this thing to heart
tn.text: The phrase "take something to heart" means "to worry about it." AT: "Do not worry about what has happened" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that she did not marry.
"did not speak"

tn.ref: It came about after two full years
tn.text: This explains that two whole years has passed and introduces the next event in the story line. The phrase "full years" means that they are complete years. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
These are people who cut the wool from sheep.
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a phrase used to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Absalom is calling himself "your servant" to show respect.
It was customary for people in Israel to have a party after they had sheared their sheep.
Although he is talking to his father the king, he calls him "the king" instead of "you" to show respect for him.

tn.ref: please let my brother Amnon go with us
tn.text: The oldest son could often represent his father in Israelite culture. Amnon was David's oldest son.

tn.ref: Why should Amnon go with you?
tn.text: David knew that Amnon was not Absalom's friend.

Here the author speaks of Absalom urging David to let Amnon come as if he were putting physical pressure on him. AT: "Absalom begged David for Amnon to come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This implies that they do not need to be afraid of the consequences for killing Amnon. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Do not be afraid that you will be blamed for killing the king's son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Absalom asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that he will be blamed for killing Amnon because he is commanding them. This can be written as a statement. AT: "I have commanded you to do this." or "I will be the one guilty for killing him because I have commanded you to do this." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
What Absalom has commanded them to do may be stated in the question. AT: "not commanded you to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

This does not include Absalom and Amnon who is dead. It includes the rest of the sons that the king allowed to go to the celebration. AT: "the rest of the king's sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers to the king's sons who left the celebration.
"It happened that." This phrase is used here to introduce the next event in the storyline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"travelling along the road"

tn.ref: that the news came to David saying
tn.text: Here it says that the news came, when really someone came and told David the news. AT: "that someone came and reported the news to David saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Then the king stood up"

tn.ref: tore his clothes, and lay on the floor
tn.text: He did these things to show that he was extremely sad. AT: "tore his clothes, and threw himself on the floor grieving" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
They did this to show their sadness and to mourn with their king. AT: "and tore their clothes, mourning with the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Translate these men's names as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:13:03|13:03]].

tn.ref: let not my master the king
tn.text: "my master the king, do not"

This means that the servant was watching for enemies while guarding at the city wall. AT: "who was guarding" or "who was guarding at the city wall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the servant looking up at something is spoken of as if he lifted up his eyes. AT: "looked up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This phrase is used to introduce the next event in the storyline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"for his son Amnon"

tn.text: "where he stayed for three years"

tn.ref: The mind of King David longed
tn.text: Here David is referred to by his mind to emphasize his thoughts. AT: "King David longed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: for he was comforted concerning Amnon and his death
tn.text: "because he was no longer grieving about Amnon being dead" (UDB). This refers to three years after Absalom fled to Geshur.
